title: What are the reasons Greek literature is considered universal? - Quora

response.answer_text: Part of the reason is that it works with such fundamental themes and elemental components. In Greek mythology, each of the primary gods embodies some elemental aspect of human psychology. Ares is violence and war. Athena is wisdom. Aphrodite is love and beauty. Hera is jealous and vengeful.  When these gods intervene in human affairs--and they often do in Greek literature--they're personifying aspects of the human psyche inside all of us that are active all the time, in every little thing we do.  Think about having an argument with a friend or loved one. You're full of anger and love at the same time, and part of your mind is counseling wisdom so you don't make a bad situation worse.  This is like a microcosm of the Greek epics, in which each of the gods vies to influence the outcome of events. Or, you could say, the epics show to some extent what we all experience internally as we navigate our daily lives. Greek mythology also includes primal forces over which even the gods have no control. The fates and the furies simply have their way with people, and can bring great fortune or inexplicable catastrophe with no rhyme or reason. We've all experienced that too. That general mythology made its way into poetry and drama, which were forms that could be repeated or re-enacted without needing to be written. That is, they could spread in a pre-literate culture. When the Greeks did start writing, they produced some phenomenally good work which the Romans, and later the Christian monks found to be worth preserving. Some people say that all of Western philosophy is an elaboration on Plato, and having read a lot of Western philosophy, I tend to agree. In the natural world there are only 100 or so elements, and literally everything in the world is built from those. Plato and the Greek dramatists and poets identified and examined many of the fundamental elements of their subjects. Later generations of writers learned from them and built on top of their knowledge. So that influence carries through to today.

Let me give you an example. Some days ago Turkey’s President, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, overcame a violent military coup. He may or may not have been forewarned about this and the coup may or may not have been backed by “foreign secret services”; yet the fact remains that he is currently using the coup as an excuse to purge the country from every dissident he can get his hands on. From military personnel and diplomats to journalists and academics they are either fired or jailed awaiting trial - with the imminent return of the death penalty looming over them. And here is where it gets eerie: Erdoğan went on to order all the supporters of the coup who were killed in the process not to receive proper burials. The mayor of Constantinople (present-day Istanbul) dully obliged to this but will everyone obey such an order, including the families of the deceased and the most devout members of the clergy? Now, let’s go back 2,500 years, to 5th century BC Athens when the dramatic writer Sophocles first presented his classic theatrical play Antigone. It is a story with quite a long background but it boils down to this: the king of Thebes, Creon, in a moment of prideful hubris, he too ordered the leader of the faction opposing him in the civil war, Polyneices, to remain unburied in order to shame him. Yet, Polyneices’ sister, Antigone, when faced with the dilemma, she decides to defy the king’s orders and honor her brother with a proper burial, knowing full well that she will get caught and punished by death. When later she is brought before the king she declares the moral law that all humans contain within our psyche to far surpass any law set by mortal rulers. The king’s nemesis (moral turmoil) ensues and he does repent and change course in the end - but not before he suffers the inevitable katharsis (cleansing) that removes the hubris and restores the moral balance. Because, once she makes her difficult choice, Antigone’s path is unwavering. The truly tragic figure is Creon, getting entangled in his inflated pride and wanting to dispense justice as he saw fit - only to destroy everything and loose everyone in the process.   What are the reasons Greek literature is considered to be universal, you ask? Because, even if only a fraction of it was saved intact throughout the centuries, there is not a single aspect of the human condition not described and resolved within it. From unearthing the influences of deep Oedipal complexes to warning about the corruption of power and from describing the perils of human pathos to reproducing every hue of our common emotions, the epic sagas, the lyric poems, the plays, and the novels covered it all. Antigone has been performed (or taught, to employ the classical Greek expression) innumerous times over the next two and a half millennia. The first picture is from a classic iteration of the play with the legendary Greek actress of the 1960’s, Irene Papas, whereas the second one is from a modern interpretation by the US National Theater with Jodie Whittaker, some years ago.
